Award.AwardTitle: Formation of Non-Pathogenic E. Coli Biofilms on Silicone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-Technical: This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to University of Houston is to carry out research that will provide new insights to the process of biofilm formation, which will be invaluable for the development of strategies to prevent pathogen colonization and to promote the formation of benign or 'antimicrobial' biofilms. Colonization by pathogenic bacteria and the subsequent formation of biofilms on hosts, materials, and devices have a tremendous negative impact on human health and the environment. The proposed research is to develop a new strategy that uses benign bacteria to form a high coverage and stable biofilm on silicone surfaces to prevent biofilm formation by pathogenic bacteria. Graduate and undergraduate students involved in the project will be trained in many cutting-edge research skills and fields. Additionally, one undergraduate student per year will be recruited and mentored under the 'teachHouston' program at the campus to train as K-12 teachers in STEM topics. This program was established to address the critical shortage of K-12 science teachers. Students in the program not only do research in the researcher's laboratory, but also teach at local schools from their first year. The goal of the program is to provide high quality research experience to the future teachers so that they can better inspire young minds to scientific inquiry. Towards this end, this investigator will help these students to develop education modules related to their research projects for use in high school science classes.

Technical: Biofilm formation by pathogenic microbes is involved in most bacterial diseases, especially biomedical device-associated infections. Pathogens enclosed in biofilms are protected from host immune defense and antimicrobial agents. Hence, they are difficult to eradicate, resulting in recurrent infections and facilitating the development of multidrug resistance. The overarching goal of the proposed research is to develop a new strategy to prevent biofilm formation on silicone surfaces used in urinary catheters and associated bacterial infection. This strategy uses benign bacteria to form a high coverage and stable biofilm on silicone surfaces as a live base to fight against pathogens. The objectives of the proposed research are to modify silicone surfaces with adhesion molecules to enable benign bacteria to form high coverage and stable biofilms, and to investigate the bacterial responses to the immobilized adhesion molecules during the biofilm formation process. The new understanding will guide the development of benign biofilms to fight against pathogens. Students involved in the project will be trained in this multidisciplinary area. To train future science teachers, one undergraduate student per year will be recruited from the 'teachHouston' program at the campus, and will be trained as teachers in education modules for use in high school chemistry and biology classes, in addition to their research activities in the researcher's laboratory.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Bacterial colonization and biofilm formation have a tremendous impact on human health, the environment, agriculture, and energy. This project aims to advance the molecular level understanding on how bacteria form biofilms on model silicone surfaces presenting carbohydrate ligands, and to develop methods to promote formation of nonpathogenic biofilms for long-term protection of biomaterial surfaces against pathogen colonization. Silicone is a common material used in biomedical devices, such as urinary catheters. Pathogen colonization on urinary catheters causes catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI) as a common hospital acquired infection.  We have modified silicone surfaces with a series of carbohydrates, including mannoside derivatives and poly(N-acetylglucosamine) (PNAG) derivatives. The mannose derivatives have a wide range of binding affinities to the receptor (fimH) at the tip of type 1 fimbriae on many bacterial species, and the PNAG derivatives are found in many bacterial biofilms. In this project, we study the biofilm formation by a strain of non-pathogenic bacteria, E. coli 83972 that have the type 1 fimbriae.   Our result indicated that the immobilized PNAG alone was not sufficient to generate high coverage and stable E. coli 83972 biofilms. On the other hand, the growth rate and stability of the E. coli biofilms increased with the binding affinity of the mannosides to the bacteria. Significantly, we showed that the non-pathogenic E. coli 83972 biofilms grown on a high affinity mannoside surface were able to prevent the colonization by six pathogenic bacterial strains tested in this study for more than 10 days. 

To gain an understanding of the process to form the biofilms, we analyzed the extracellular polymeric substances (EPS) that are produced and secreted by the bacteria during biofilm formation. EPS are responsible to the bacteria-surface binding and inter-bacteria binding, and they are the major component of the bacteria biofilms. Using a state-of-the-art mass spectrometry system (Bruker timsTOF Pro), we have identified up to 1220 protein groups in the EPS of the E. coli 83972 biofilms deposited on various mannose-modified silicone surfaces. Over 40% of them had more than 2-fold changes among various surfaces. This result indicated that the immobilized mannose derivatives with a wide range of binding affinities to bacterial fimbriae significantly affected the proteomic composition of the EPS that is expected to influence the biofilm properties, including stability of the biofilms and their efficiency for inhibiting the colonization by pathogens. The substantial difference in the EPS protein compositions determined for the biofilms on various mannoside surfaces indicates that the initial mannoside-FimH binding may trigger the production and secretion of the EPS whose amount and composition depend on the strength of the mannoside-FimH binding. 

In addition to gaining new knowledge on how biofilm properties can be affected by materials interface, we have developed several methods and tools for study of biofilm formation on biomaterial surfaces and for characterization of EPS as an important type of biomaterials. Specifically, we developed a practical method for biofunctionalization of silicone substrates, including the inner lumen of catheters. We have optimized the workflow for preparation of the “real” EPS samples devoid of contamination by cytosolic contents due to compromised cell membrane. In addition, we have developed a sample preparation workflow for processing sub-nanogram amounts of EPS proteins for mass spectrometry-based identification and quantification. This workflow can be used for analysis of the EPS proteins secreted at the beginning of the biofilm formation. Furthermore, we have developed one of the most efficient high-throughput flow biofilm model system consisting of an array of 34 silicone catheters for studying (polymicrobial) biofilms grown on catheters under flow conditions over a long period of time (weeks).

In summary, results from this project indicate that the specific interactions between bacteria and the immobilized ligand (mannosides) profoundly influence the biofilm long-term stability through secretion of EPS whose composition depends on the ligand-receptor binding strengths. Although such interactions only involve the bottom layer of bacteria, the effect/signal generated appears to propagate through many layers of bacteria in the biofilm and over many generations of bacteria. It demonstrates the possibility to control the biofilm properties by the presentation of specific ligands on surfaces. Overall, our work contributes to the advancement of the understanding of biofilm formation, especially the role of immobilized ligands. This improved understanding may inform the development of new strategies to prevent the formation of harmful biofilms and promote the growth of beneficial biofilms. Finally, fifteen undergraduate and six graduate students were involved in the project, and were trained in the highly interdisciplinary research. Three graduate students graduated with a PhD degree and are now working in academia and industry, and three former undergraduate students are studying in graduate schools in STEM fields.
